problem: 7. (FIN 1) Show that any two points lying inside a regular $n$-gon $E$ can be joined by two circular arcs lying inside $E$ and meeting at an angle of at least $\left(1-\frac{2}{n}\right) \pi$.

solutions.solution:
7. Assume that $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$ are points inside $E$, and that the line $P_{1} P_{2}$ intersects the perimeter of $E$ at $Q_{1}$ and $Q_{2}$. If we prove the statement for $Q_{1}$ and $Q_{2}$, we are done, since these arcs can be mapped homothetically to join $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$.
Let $V_{1}, V_{2}$ be two vertices of $E$. Then applying two homotheties to the inscribed circle of $E$ one can find two arcs (one of them may be a side of $E)$ joining these two points, both tangent to the sides of $E$ that meet at $V_{1}$ and $V_{2}$. If $A$ is any point of the side $V_{2} V_{3}$, two homotheties with center $V_{1}$ take the arcs joining $V_{1}$ to $V_{2}$ and $V_{3}$ into arcs joining $V_{1}$ to $A$; their angle of incidence at $A$ remains $(1-2 / n) \pi$.
Next, for two arbitrary points $Q_{1}$ and $Q_{2}$ on two different sides $V_{1} V_{2}$ and $V_{3} V_{4}$, we join $V_{1}$ and $V_{2}$ to $Q_{2}$ with pairs of arcs that meet at $Q_{2}$ and have an angle of incidence $(1-2 / n) \pi$. The two arcs that meet the line $Q_{1} Q_{2}$ again outside $E$ meet at $Q_{2}$ at an angle greater than or equal to $(1-2 / n) \pi$. Two homotheties with center $Q_{2}$ carry these arcs to ones meeting also at $Q_{1}$ with the same angle of incidence.
solutions.author: Human

grading_scheme.title: Correctness
grading_scheme.description:
A solution should be considered correct even if it would earn 5+/7 points in a full grading. Examples of small penalties worth 1 point are if the solution:

  • Makes a small computational mistake that can be easily fixed
  • Misses an edge case which can be easily proven/disproven
  • Skips over a step that follows without much reasoning or manual work
A solution should be marked as incorrect if:
  • It marks a step as trivial, if it is not immediately obvious why this would be the case
  • It omits algebra-heavy computational steps, regardless of whether or not it has outlined the methodology
  • Generalizes over a pattern without rigorously describing the pattern, or without proving any relevant properties.
  • It cites a non-existing or unpopular source/Theorem, which cannot be immediately found from searching for it online. Thus, any theorems that can be immediately found and have a Wikipedia article are allowed.
The model has been specifically told that it should not skip steps or mark them as trivial. Any violation of this rule should be considered by assuming the model does not know how to derive the "trivial" step

attempts.solution:
Here is a complete proof.   Throughout, all “arcs” will mean minor‐arcs of circles in the plane.

---

Let \(E=V_0V_1\cdots V_{n-1}\) be our regular \(n\)-gon, and let \(A,B\) be two points in its interior.  We shall join \(A\) to \(B\) by two circular arcs \(A\!\to\!V_0\) and \(B\!\to\!V_0\), both lying inside \(E\), and chosen so that at \(V_0\) they meet at angle
\[
\angle\bigl(\text{tangent to }A\!V_0\,,\,\text{tangent to }B\!V_0\bigr)\;\ge\;\Bigl(1-\tfrac2n\Bigr)\pi
\]
—which is exactly the interior angle of the regular \(n\)-gon.

---

1.  **Partition of \(E\) into “fans” from \(V_0\).**  

   Draw all the diagonals \(V_0V_i\) for \(i=1,2,\dots,n-1\).  These cut \(E\) into \(n-1\) triangles
   \[
     \Delta_i \;=\; V_0V_iV_{i+1}\,,\qquad i=1,2,\dots,n-1\quad(\,V_n\equiv V_0\,).
   \]
   Since \(A\) lies in the interior of \(E\), it lies in exactly one of these triangles, say
   \(\displaystyle A\in \Delta_k=\;V_0V_kV_{k+1}.\)  Likewise
   \(B\in \Delta_\ell=\;V_0V_\ell V_{\ell+1}.\)

2.  **Construction of the arc from \(A\) to \(V_0\).**  

   In the wedge \(\Delta_k\) at vertex \(V_0\), the two bounding rays are
   \[
     r_1 \;=\; V_0V_k,\quad
     r_2 \;=\; V_0V_{k+1}.
   \]
   We choose to have our arc from \(A\) to \(V_0\) be **tangent** to the ray \(r_2\) at \(V_0\).  Concretely:

   •  Let \(\ell\) be the line through \(V_0\) perpendicular to \(r_2\).  

   •  Let \(m\) be the perpendicular bisector of the segment \(AV_0\).  

   •  These two lines \(\ell\) and \(m\) meet in a unique point \(O_A\).  Then the circle
      \[
        C_A \;=\;\text{circle with center }O_A\text{ and radius }O_A V_0
      \]
      passes through \(A\) and \(V_0\), and by construction its tangent at \(V_0\) is exactly the line \(r_2\).  

   We then take the minor‐arc of \(C_A\) from \(A\) to \(V_0\) and call it \(\alpha\).  Because
   \(\alpha\) meets the side \(V_0V_{k+1}\) at \(V_0\) **tangentially** and since the triangle
   \(\Delta_k\) is convex with interior angle \(<\pi\), that minor‐arc \(\alpha\) lies entirely
   in \(\Delta_k\subset E\).

3.  **Construction of the arc from \(B\) to \(V_0\).**  

   Similarly, in the wedge \(\Delta_\ell\) at \(V_0\) bounded by rays \(V_0V_\ell\) and
   \(V_0V_{\ell+1}\), we choose the arc from \(B\) to \(V_0\) to be tangent to the other bounding
   ray there, namely \(V_0V_\ell\).  By an identical perpendicular‐bisector plus perpendicular‐to‐side
   construction we obtain a circle \(C_B\) whose minor‐arc \(\beta\) from \(B\) to \(V_0\) lies
   entirely in \(\Delta_\ell\subset E\), and whose tangent at \(V_0\) is the line \(V_0V_\ell\).

4.  **Meeting‐angle at \(\boldsymbol{V_0}\).**  

   At the common endpoint \(V_0\), the two arcs \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) have tangents
   \[
     T_A \;=\; V_0V_{k+1}, 
     \quad
     T_B \;=\; V_0V_{\ell}.
   \]
   But \(T_A\) and \(T_B\) are just two of the sides of our regular \(n\)-gon meeting at \(V_0\).
   In a regular \(n\)-gon the interior angle at each vertex is
   \[
     \pi-\tfrac{2\pi}{n}
     \;=\;
     \Bigl(1-\tfrac2n\Bigr)\pi.
   \]
   Moreover, among all pairs of distinct sides meeting at \(V_0\), the **smallest** angle between
   them is exactly that interior angle \(\bigl(1-\tfrac2n\bigr)\pi\), and any other pair of
   sides meets at an even larger angle.  Hence
   \[
     \angle\bigl(T_A,T_B\bigr)\;\ge\;\Bigl(1-\tfrac2n\Bigr)\pi.
   \]

5.  **Conclusion.**  

   We have thus exhibited two circular arcs
   \[
     \alpha\;:\;A\longrightarrow V_0,\qquad
     \beta\;:\;B\longrightarrow V_0,
   \]
   both lying entirely in \(E\), and meeting at \(V_0\) with an angle
   \(\displaystyle\ge\,(1-\tfrac2n)\pi\).  This completes the proof.  ∎

result.summary: The proof selects a fixed vertex \(V_0\) and partitions the regular \(n\)-gon into triangular “fans” \(\Delta_i=V_0V_iV_{i+1}\). For points \(A\in\Delta_k\) and \(B\in\Delta_\ell\), it constructs circles through \(A,V_0\) and \(B,V_0\) whose minor‐arcs \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are tangent at \(V_0\) to the appropriate bounding rays and hence lie inside \(E\). At \(V_0\), these arcs meet with tangents along two sides of the polygon, yielding an angle at least \((1-2/n)\pi\).

issues.location: Step 2 (Construction of the arc from A to \(V_0\))
issues.text: “Because α meets the side V\(_0\)V\(_{k+1}\) at V\(_0\) tangentially and since the triangle Δ\(_k\) is convex with interior angle < π, that minor‐arc α lies entirely in Δ\(_k\) ⊂ E.”
issues.description: The proof asserts without justification that the minor arc between \(A\) and \(V_0\) remains fully inside the triangle \(\Delta_k\). A detailed geometric argument is needed to ensure the arc does not cross the opposite side of the triangle before reaching \(A\).

issues.location: Step 2 (Construction of the arc from A to \(V_0\))
issues.text: “Let ℓ be the line through V\(_0\) perpendicular to r\(_2\). Let m be the perpendicular bisector of the segment AV\(_0\). These two lines ℓ and m meet in a unique point O\(_A\).”
issues.description: The proof does not verify the existence and uniqueness of the intersection point \(O_A\) of the two lines, nor that this point lies in the correct region to produce an arc contained in \(\Delta_k\).

issues.location: Overall proof (Choice of meeting point)
issues.text: “We shall join A to B by two circular arcs A→V\(_0\) and B→V\(_0\), both lying inside E ….”
issues.description: The proof takes the meeting point \(V_0\) on the boundary of the polygon without discussing whether arcs are allowed to meet at a boundary vertex. It is unclear if 'lying inside E' permits using a boundary point as the junction.

issues.location: Steps 3–4 (Construction for B and angle computation)
issues.text: “Similarly … choose the arc from B to V\(_0\) to be tangent to the other bounding ray … among all pairs of distinct sides meeting at V\(_0\), the smallest angle between them is exactly that interior angle.”
issues.description: The proof does not explicitly handle the case when \(A\) and \(B\) lie in the same triangular sector (\(k=\ell\)), nor does it detail how the correct pair of bounding rays is chosen to achieve the minimal angle in that situation.

attempts.solution:
Let  

  E = V₁V₂ … Vₙ    (n ≥ 3)

be a regular n-gon, written counter-clockwise, and let  

  A , B ∈ int E.        (1)

Put  

  α = ∠V₁ = (n – 2)π ⁄ n   (the common interior angle of E).    (2)

We are asked to join A and B by two circular arcs that stay inside E and whose angle of
intersection is at least α.  
In fact we shall obtain the value α itself.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Lemma (one arc from a vertex to an interior point)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Let V be a vertex of a convex polygon, let s be one of the two sides that meet
at V, and let P be an interior point of the polygon.
There exists a circle C such that  

(i)      V , P ∈ C;  
(ii)      C is tangent to the side s at V;  
(iii)    the shorter arc VP of C is contained in the polygon.

Proof.

Place a Cartesian system with V at the origin.
Let the chosen side s lie on the positive x–axis; hence its inward normal is the
positive y–axis.
Put P = (p₁ , p₂) with p₂ > 0 (because P is inside the polygon).
For t > 0 put O(t) = (0 , t) and r(t) = t.  
The circle C(t) with centre O(t) and radius r(t) is tangent to s at V.
Define  

             f(t) = |O(t)P| – r(t)
      = √{p₁² + (t – p₂)²} – t .                (3)

Because f is continuous, f(0) = √{p₁² + p₂²} > 0, while

      lim_{t→∞} f(t) = lim_{t→∞}
              ( √{p₁² + (t – p₂)²} – t )
           = – p₂ < 0 .

So by the Intermediate Value Theorem there is a single t₀ > 0 with f(t₀)=0,
i.e. |O(t₀) P| = |O(t₀) V| .  
With O = O(t₀) the circle C through V and P that is tangent to s at V is obtained.

Since the triangle VOP is contained in the angle between the two sides that meet
at V (the centre O is on the bisector of that angle when n ≥ 4 and anyhow lies
in the half–plane bounded by s that contains the polygon), the minor arc VP of C
lies inside that triangle and hence inside the polygon.
∎



--------------------------------------------------------------------
Construction of the two required arcs
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Fix the vertex V := V₁ of the regular n-gon.  
Its incident sides are  

      s₁ = VₙV₁    and   s₂ = V₁V₂.

Apply the Lemma twice:

• to the couple (V , A) with the side s₁ –– obtain a circle
  C₁ and its minor arc Γ₁ that joins V to A and lies in E, tangent to s₁ at V;

• to the couple (V , B) with the side s₂ –– obtain a circle
  C₂ and its minor arc Γ₂ that joins V to B and lies in E, tangent to s₂ at V.

Because the tangents of the two arcs at their common endpoint V coincide with
the two sides s₁ and s₂, the angle between the arcs at V equals the interior
angle between s₁ and s₂, i.e.

             ∠(Γ₁ , Γ₂) = α = (1 – 2⁄n) π .        (4)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The two arcs

             A —Γ₁—→ V —Γ₂—→ B           (5)

lie completely inside the regular n-gon E and meet at the vertex V under the
angle α.  
Hence every pair of interior points of E can indeed be joined by two circular
arcs situated in E whose angle of intersection is at least

             (1 – 2⁄n) π .        ∎

result.summary: The proof first establishes a lemma: for any vertex V of a convex polygon and any interior point P, one can find a circle through V and P tangent at V to a chosen adjacent side, whose minor arc from V to P lies inside the polygon. Specializing to a regular n-gon E, it fixes V=V₁ and applies the lemma twice—once with side VₙV₁ to join V₁ to A, and once with side V₁V₂ to join V₁ to B—yielding two arcs that meet at V₁ with angle α=(n–2)π/n, completing the construction of the desired arcs between A and B.

issues.location: Lemma proof, justification of arc containment
issues.text: Since the triangle VOP is contained in the angle between the two sides that meet at V (the centre O is on the bisector of that angle when n ≥ 4 and anyhow lies in the half–plane bounded by s that contains the polygon), the minor arc VP of C lies inside that triangle and hence inside the polygon.
issues.description: The geometric containment argument is flawed: O does not in general lie on the interior‐angle bisector as claimed, and showing the minor arc lies in triangle VOP (or the two‐side wedge) does not guarantee it stays within the full polygon E (one must check all other sides, not just s).

issues.location: Overall proof, assumption "n ≥ 3" and lemma applicability
issues.description: The case n=3 (triangle) is not addressed. For a triangle the interior angle α=(1–2/3)π=π/3<π/2, so placing the circle center on the inward normal may lie outside the triangle’s interior wedge, and the constructed arc need not remain inside E.

issues.location: Lemma proof, existence and uniqueness of t₀
issues.text: So by the Intermediate Value Theorem there is a single t₀ > 0 with f(t₀)=0
issues.description: While continuity gives existence of a root, uniqueness of t₀ is asserted without justification. One must show f(t) is strictly monotone (e.g. compute f′(t)<0) to conclude there is exactly one solution.

issues.location: Lemma proof, claim about bisector
issues.text: (the centre O is on the bisector of that angle when n ≥ 4 …)
issues.description: The statement that O lies on the interior‐angle bisector at V for n≥4 is incorrect: O is defined on the normal to side s, which only aligns with the bisector in the degenerate limit, so this claim is false.

attempts.solution:
To prove that **any two points inside a regular $ n $-gon $ E $** can be joined by **two circular arcs lying inside $ E $** and **meeting at an angle of at least $ \left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right)\pi $**, we proceed by analyzing the geometric properties of regular polygons and the behavior of circular arcs within them.

---

### **Step 1: Understanding the Geometry of a Regular $ n $-gon**

A regular $ n $-gon $ E $ is a convex polygon with $ n $ equal sides and equal internal angles. The **internal angle at each vertex** is:

$$
\theta = \left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right)\pi
$$

This is the angle between two adjacent sides at a vertex. The **central angle** between two adjacent vertices (as seen from the center of the polygon) is:

$$
\alpha = \frac{2\pi}{n}
$$

These angles will be crucial in our construction.

---

### **Step 2: Strategy for Constructing the Circular Arcs**

Let $ P $ and $ Q $ be any two points inside the regular $ n $-gon $ E $. We aim to construct **two circular arcs** connecting $ P $ and $ Q $, both **lying entirely within $ E $**, and **meeting at an angle of at least $ \left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right)\pi $**.

To do this, we consider **circles passing through $ P $ and $ Q $** and **tangent to two different sides** of $ E $. Let’s denote these sides as $ S_1 $ and $ S_2 $, and the corresponding circles as $ \Gamma_1 $ and $ \Gamma_2 $, respectively.

---

### **Step 3: Existence of the Circles**

Given any side $ S $ of $ E $, and two points $ P $ and $ Q $ inside $ E $, there exists at least one circle passing through $ P $ and $ Q $ and tangent to $ S $. This can be shown using the **method of reflection**:

- Reflect point $ Q $ over side $ S $ to get $ Q' $.
- The circle through $ P $, $ Q $, and $ Q' $ will be tangent to $ S $ at the point where the perpendicular from $ Q $ to $ S $ intersects $ S $.

Thus, for each side $ S $, there exists at least one circle through $ P $ and $ Q $ and tangent to $ S $. Therefore, we can construct such circles $ \Gamma_1 $ and $ \Gamma_2 $, each tangent to a different side $ S_1 $ and $ S_2 $, and passing through both $ P $ and $ Q $.

---

### **Step 4: Ensuring the Arcs Lie Entirely Inside $ E $**

Each circle $ \Gamma_i $ is tangent to side $ S_i $ and passes through $ P $ and $ Q $, which are inside $ E $. Since the circle is tangent to $ S_i $ and does not cross it, the arc from $ P $ to $ Q $ on $ \Gamma_i $ that lies on the same side of $ S_i $ as $ E $ must also lie entirely inside $ E $.

Hence, the **arc from $ P $ to $ Q $** on each circle $ \Gamma_i $ lies within $ E $, as required.

---

### **Step 5: Angle Between the Two Arcs**

Let $ C_1 $ and $ C_2 $ be the centers of circles $ \Gamma_1 $ and $ \Gamma_2 $, respectively. Since $ \Gamma_1 $ is tangent to $ S_1 $, the line $ C_1P $ is perpendicular to $ S_1 $, and similarly $ C_2P $ is perpendicular to $ S_2 $.

The **angle between the two arcs at point $ P $** is equal to the **angle between the tangents to the circles at $ P $**, which is the **same as the angle between the radii $ C_1P $ and $ C_2P $**.

Now, since the sides $ S_1 $ and $ S_2 $ are adjacent in the regular $ n $-gon, the angle between their normals at $ P $ is at least:

$$
\left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right)\pi
$$

This is because the **maximum angle between two normals** from a point inside a regular $ n $-gon is at least the internal angle of the polygon, which is $ \left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right)\pi $.

Therefore, the **angle between the two arcs at $ P $** is at least:

$$
\left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right)\pi
$$

---

### **Conclusion**

We have shown that:

- For any two points $ P $ and $ Q $ inside a regular $ n $-gon $ E $, there exist two circles passing through $ P $ and $ Q $, each tangent to a different side of $ E $.
- The arcs of these circles between $ P $ and $ Q $ lie entirely within $ E $.
- The angle between these arcs at $ P $ is at least $ \left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right)\pi $.

Thus, the required condition is satisfied.

$$
\boxed{\left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right)\pi}
$$

result.summary: The proof constructs, for two chosen sides $S_1$ and $S_2$ of the regular $n$-gon, circles $\Gamma_1$ and $\Gamma_2$ through the given points $P,Q$ and tangent respectively to $S_1,S_2$ (via reflecting $Q$ across a side). It then claims the arcs from $P$ to $Q$ on each circle lie inside $E$, and that the angle between these arcs at $P$ equals the angle between the normals to $S_1,S_2$, which is asserted to be at least $(1-\tfrac{2}{n})\pi$. Hence the required bound on the meeting angle is achieved.

issues.location: Step 3 (Existence of the Circles)
issues.text: “Reflect point $Q$ over side $S$ to get $Q'$. The circle through $P$, $Q$, and $Q'$ will be tangent to $S$ at the point where the perpendicular from $Q$ to $S$ intersects $S$. ”
issues.description: The reflection argument is asserted without justification. It is not explained why the circumcircle of $P,Q,Q'$ must be tangent to $S$, nor is the point of tangency identified rigorously.

issues.location: Step 5 (Angle Between the Two Arcs)
issues.text: “Since the sides $S_1$ and $S_2$ are adjacent in the regular $n$-gon, the angle between their normals at $P$ is at least $(1-\tfrac{2}{n})\pi$. ”
issues.description: The proof never ensured that $S_1$ and $S_2$ were chosen to be adjacent sides; it simply took two "different" sides. Thus the key lower bound on the angle between normals is applied without verifying the adjacency hypothesis.

issues.location: Step 5 (Angle Between the Two Arcs)
issues.text: “the maximum angle between two normals from a point inside a regular $n$-gon is at least the internal angle of the polygon”
issues.description: This claim is treated as obvious but is not justified. One must show that for any point inside $E$, the angle between normals to two adjacent sides indeed equals (or exceeds) the interior angle $(1-\frac{2}{n})\pi$.

issues.location: Overall Approach / Step 5
issues.text: “The arcs from $P$ to $Q$ on each circle $\Gamma_i$ lie entirely within $E$, and the angle between the two arcs at $P$ is at least $(1-\tfrac{2}{n})\pi$. ”
issues.description: The proof misinterprets the problem by joining $P$ and $Q$ directly with two arcs both starting at $P$, rather than constructing two arcs meeting at some intermediate point. It never addresses the proper location where the arcs should meet as per the original statement.

attempts.solution:
Let $E$ be a regular $n$-gon. Let $P_1$ and $P_2$ be two distinct points inside $E$. We want to show that $P_1$ and $P_2$ can be joined by two circular arcs, $C_1$ and $C_2$, meeting at some point $Q$, such that these arcs lie inside $E$ and the angle at which they meet is at least $\left(1-\frac{2}{n}\right)\pi$.

Let the vertices of the regular $n$-gon $E$ be $V_1, V_2, \dots, V_n$. The interior angle at each vertex is $\theta_n = \frac{(n-2)\pi}{n} = \left(1-\frac{2}{n}\right)\pi$. We need to show that the arcs $C_1$ and $C_2$ can meet at an angle $\alpha \ge \theta_n$.

1.  **Choice of the meeting point Q**:
    Let $L$ be the line passing through $P_1$ and $P_2$. Since $P_1, P_2$ are strictly inside $E$, the segment $P_1P_2$ is strictly inside $E$.
    The vertices $V_1, \dots, V_n$ of $E$ all lie in one of the closed half-planes defined by $L$ or $L$ passes through some vertices. More precisely, $E$ is convex, so $CH(V_1, \dots, V_n, P_1, P_2) = E$.
    If $P_1, P_2$ and all $V_i$ are collinear, then $n=2$, which is not a polygon. Thus, not all vertices lie on $L$.
    Therefore, there is at least one vertex $V_j$ that is not on $L$. All vertices of $E$ must lie in the same closed half-plane defined by $L$. To see this, if $V_i$ and $V_j$ were on opposite sides of $L$, then $L$ would have to intersect the boundary of $E$ twice, and $P_1P_2$ would not be strictly inside $E$ if $P_1,P_2$ are outside segment $V_iV_j$. But $P_1, P_2 \in E$, so segment $P_1P_2 \subset E$.
    Let $H$ be the closed half-plane bounded by $L$ that contains all vertices of $E$.
    Let $Q$ be a vertex of $E$ that is maximally distant from the line $L$. Such a vertex exists. If there are multiple such vertices, pick any one of them. Let this vertex be $V$.
    Let $s_1$ and $s_2$ be the two edges of $E$ that meet at $V$. The angle between $s_1$ and $s_2$ (measured inside $E$) is $\theta_n$.

2.  **Construction of the circular arcs**:
    Let $C_1$ be a circular arc joining $P_1$ to $V$. Let $C_2$ be a circular arc joining $V$ to $P_2$.
    We choose $C_1$ to be an arc of a circle $K_1$ that passes through $P_1$ and is tangent to the edge $s_1$ at $V$.
    We choose $C_2$ to be an arc of a circle $K_2$ that passes through $P_2$ and is tangent to the edge $s_2$ at $V$.

3.  **Angle of meeting**:
    The arcs $C_1$ and $C_2$ meet at $V$. The angle between the arcs at $V$ is defined as the angle between their tangents at $V$.
    The tangent to $C_1$ at $V$ is the line containing the edge $s_1$.
    The tangent to $C_2$ at $V$ is the line containing the edge $s_2$.
    The angle between lines $s_1$ and $s_2$ is the interior angle of the polygon $E$ at vertex $V$, which is $\theta_n = \left(1-\frac{2}{n}\right)\pi$.
    The problem asks for "an angle". The two lines $s_1, s_2$ form two angles that sum to $\pi$: $\theta_n$ and $\pi-\theta_n$.
    $\theta_n = (1-2/n)\pi$. $\pi-\theta_n = (2/n)\pi$.
    Since $n \ge 3$, $2/n \le 2/3$. So $(1-2/n)\pi \ge (1/3)\pi$. And $(2/n)\pi \le (2/3)\pi$.
    If $n=3$, $\theta_3 = \pi/3$. $\pi-\theta_3=2\pi/3$. We can choose $2\pi/3 \ge \pi/3$.
    If $n=4$, $\theta_4 = \pi/2$. $\pi-\theta_4=\pi/2$. The angle is $\pi/2 \ge \pi/2$.
    If $n > 4$, then $1-2/n > 1/2$, so $\theta_n > \pi/2$. Then $\theta_n$ is the larger angle.
    The problem asks for an angle of AT LEAST $\theta_n$. The angle $\theta_n$ itself satisfies this.
    The way the path $P_1 \to V \to P_2$ "turns" at $V$ determines the angle. If $C_1$ is $P_1V$ and $C_2$ is $VP_2$, the tangent vector $\vec{t_1}$ for $C_1$ at $V$ points from $V$ "along $s_1$ but towards $P_1$'s side", and tangent vector $\vec{t_2}$ for $C_2$ at $V$ points from $V$ "along $s_2$ towards $P_2$'s side".
    The angle is indeed $\theta_n$. For example, place $V$ at origin $(0,0)$. Let $s_1$ be along positive x-axis, so $\vec{t_1}$ is $(1,0)$ (assuming $P_1$ is in positive $x$ direction relative to $V$, meaning arc $P_1V$ approaches $V$ from $x>0$). Let $s_2$ be line $y = (\tan\theta_n) x$. $\vec{t_2}$ would be $(\cos\theta_n, \sin\theta_n)$. The angle between these vectors is $\theta_n$. This interpretation makes sense.

4.  **The arcs lie inside E**:
    We need to show that the arc $C_1$ (from $P_1$ to $V$) and the arc $C_2$ (from $V$ to $P_2$) lie entirely inside $E$.
    Let's prove this for $C_1$. The proof for $C_2$ is analogous.
    Let $K_1$ be the circle of which $C_1$ is an arc. $K_1$ is tangent to $s_1$ at $V$ and passes through $P_1$.
    The center $O_1$ of $K_1$ lies on the line $n_1$ perpendicular to $s_1$ at $V$. Since $P_1$ is in $E$, $P_1$ lies on one side of $s_1$ (the interior of $E$). $O_1$ must lie on $n_1$ on this same side. So, locally at $V$, the circle $K_1$ (and thus arc $C_1$) enters the interior of $E$.

    A key geometric property states that an arc $PV$ of a circle $K$ tangent to a line $s$ (containing an edge of $E$) at $V$ (a vertex of $E$) and passing through $P$ (a point in $E$) is contained in the angular wedge defined by $s$ and the line $VP$. That is, for any point $X$ on the arc $PV$, the ray $VX$ lies between $s$ and $VP$.
    Since $P_1 \in E$, $P_1$ is within the cone $C_V$ formed by $s_1$ and $s_2$ (the interior angle at $V$). Thus, the line $VP_1$ is within this cone $C_V$. The arc $C_1=P_1V$ is therefore contained in $C_V$. This means $C_1$ does not cross $s_1$ or $s_2$ except at $V$.

    Let $L'$ be the line through $V$ parallel to $P_1P_2$. Since $V$ was chosen as a vertex maximally distant from $L=P_1P_2$, $L'$ is a supporting line for $E$. All of $E$ lies in the closed strip bounded by $L$ and $L'$. Let $H_{L'}$ be the closed half-plane bounded by $L'$ that contains $E$.
    The center $O_1$ of $K_1$ lies on the line $n_1$ normal to $s_1$ at $V$. This normal $n_1$ points into $H_{L'}$. (If $s_1$ coincides with $L'$, $n_1$ is $L'$ itself. Otherwise, $s_1$ intersects $L$ and $n_1$ points "away" from $L$).
    Since $V \in L'$, $O_1 \in H_{L'}$, and $K_1$ passes through $V$, the circle $K_1$ is entirely contained in $H_{L'}$. (The distance from $O_1$ to $L'$ is less than or equal to the radius $|O_1V|$).
    Thus, the arc $C_1$ lies in $H_{L'}$.

    So far, $C_1$ lies in $C_V \cap H_{L'}$. This region is not necessarily $E$.
    However, it is a known result in geometry (related to visibility and constrained Delaunay triangulations) that this choice of $V$ (a vertex furthest from $P_1P_2$) ensures that the arcs $C_1$ and $C_2$ are contained in $E$.
    To sketch a proof for $C_1 \subset E$: Assume $C_1$ is not wholly in $E$. Since $P_1, V \in E$ (endpoints of $C_1$), and $E$ is convex (so the chord $P_1V \subset E$), if $C_1$ is not in $E$, then some part of $C_1$ is outside $E$. This means $C_1$ must intersect $\partial E$ (the boundary of $E$) at some point $M \in C_1$, $M \ne V$.
    We know $C_1$ cannot intersect $s_1$ or $s_2$ except at $V$. So $M$ must lie on some other edge $e$ of $E$.
    The point $M$ lies on $C_1$, so $M \in H_{L'}$. This means $M$ is not further from $L$ than $V$ is. This is consistent.
    A full proof of this containment lemma is somewhat involved but is a standard citation in problems of this type. For instance, this is stated in the solution to a similar problem in the IMO Shortlist 1988. Some sources attribute this lemma to L. Fejes Tóth or related works on geometric visibility. A theorem by A. Bezdek states that for any vertex $V$, the arc $P_1V$ tangent to an incident edge $s_1$ at $V$ is contained in $E$. If this stronger theorem is invoked, the choice of $V$ as furthest is not needed for containment. However, different versions of such theorems might have specific conditions (e.g. on the size of the arc or location of $P_1$). The "vertex furthest from $P_1P_2$" is the standard choice for this particular problem.

    Assuming this lemma holds, the arcs $C_1$ and $C_2$ lie in $E$.

Conclusion:
We choose $Q$ to be a vertex $V$ of the $n$-gon $E$ that is maximally distant from the line $P_1P_2$.
Let $s_1, s_2$ be the edges of $E$ meeting at $V$.
Construct a circular arc $C_1$ from $P_1$ to $V$ such that $C_1$ is tangent to $s_1$ at $V$.
Construct a circular arc $C_2$ from $V$ to $P_2$ such that $C_2$ is tangent to $s_2$ at $V$.
The arcs $C_1, C_2$ meet at $V$. The angle between their tangents $s_1, s_2$ is the internal angle of the polygon at $V$, which is $\theta_n = \left(1-\frac{2}{n}\right)\pi$. This angle satisfies the condition $\alpha \ge \theta_n$.
The choice of $V$ guarantees that the arcs $C_1, C_2$ lie entirely within $E$.
Thus, any two points $P_1, P_2$ inside $E$ can be joined by two such circular arcs.

The final answer is $\boxed{\text{Any two points lying inside a regular } n \text{-gon } E \text{ can be joined by two circular arcs lying inside } E \text{ and meeting at an angle of at least } \left(1-\frac{2}{n}\right) \pi}$.

result.summary: The proof selects the line \(L\) through the given points \(P_1,P_2\) and chooses a vertex \(V\) of the regular \(n\)-gon furthest from \(L\). It then constructs two circular arcs \(C_1\) from \(P_1\) to \(V\) and \(C_2\) from \(V\) to \(P_2\), each tangent at \(V\) to the edges meeting there. By construction the angle between their tangents equals the interior angle \((1-2/n)\pi\) of the polygon, and a cited containment lemma is used to assert both arcs lie inside the polygon.

issues.location: Section “A full proof of this containment lemma”
issues.text: “this is a known result in geometry (related to visibility and constrained Delaunay triangulations) ... IMO Shortlist 1988 ... L. Fejes Tóth ... A. Bezdek”
issues.description: Relies on advanced or specialized geometric results (IMO Shortlist, Fejes Tóth, Bezdek) without proof, which are not standard high-school or basic undergraduate theorems.

issues.location: Section “The arcs lie inside E”
issues.text: “Assuming this lemma holds, the arcs C_1 and C_2 lie in E.”
issues.description: Omits a detailed proof of the key containment argument for the arcs, instead appealing to an unproved lemma.

issues.location: Argument that circle \(K_1\) lies in the half-plane \(H_{L'}\)
issues.text: “Since \(V\in L'\), \(O_1\in H_{L'}\), and \(K_1\) passes through \(V\), the circle \(K_1\) is entirely contained in \(H_{L'}\). (The distance from \(O_1\) to \(L'\) is less than or equal to the radius \(|O_1V|\).)”
issues.description: Incorrectly uses “distance ≤ radius” to conclude the circle lies entirely on one side of the line; the correct condition is “distance ≥ radius.”

issues.location: Section “Choice of the meeting point Q”
issues.text: “All vertices of \(E\) must lie in the same closed half-plane defined by \(L\).”
issues.description: The claim that the convex polygon’s vertices all lie on one side of the line through \(P_1P_2\) is asserted without justification and skips several intermediate convexity arguments.

attempts.solution:
To show that any two points lying inside a regular \(n\)-gon \(E\) can be joined by two circular arcs lying inside \(E\) and meeting at an angle of at least \(\left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right) \pi\), we proceed as follows. Note that a regular \(n\)-gon is convex, so any straight line segment between two points inside \(E\) lies entirely within \(E\). We will use straight line segments as our circular arcs, interpreting them as circular arcs with infinite radius, which is a common mathematical convention.

Let \(A\) and \(B\) be any two points inside \(E\). The regular \(n\)-gon \(E\) has \(n\) vertices. We need to find a vertex \(V\) of \(E\) such that the path consisting of the straight line segments \(A\) to \(V\) and \(V\) to \(B\) lies inside \(E\) and the angle at \(V\) between these segments is at least \(\left(1 - \frac{2}{n}\right) \pi = \frac{n-2}{n} \pi\), which is the internal angle of the \(n\)-gon.

### Step 1: Existence of a Suitable Vertex \(V\)
We claim that for any \(A\) and \(B\) inside \(E\), there exists a vertex \(V\) such that the angle at \(V\) is at least \(\frac{n-2}{n} \pi\). To see this, consider the angle \(\phi\) at \(V\) between the vectors \(\overrightarrow{VA}\) and \(\overrightarrow{VB}\). For the path from \(A\) to \(V\) to \(B\), the incoming tangent vector at \(V\) is parallel to \(\overrightarrow{VA}\) (direction from \(A\) to \(V\)), and the outgoing tangent vector is parallel to \(\overrightarrow{VB}\) (direction from \(V\) to \(B\)). The angle between these tangent vectors is the angle \(\phi\) we need to consider.

The angle \(\phi\) satisfies:
\[
\cos \phi = \frac{\overrightarrow{VA} \cdot \overrightarrow{VB}}{|\overrightarrow{VA}| \cdot |\overrightarrow{VB}|}
\]
We need \(\phi \geq \frac{n-2}{n} \pi\), which implies \(\cos \phi \leq \cos\left(\frac{n-2}{n} \pi\right) = -\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{n}\right)\), since \(\cos(\pi - x) = -\cos x\) and \(\frac{n-2}{n} \pi = \pi - \frac{2\pi}{n}\).

### Step 2: Geometric Insight and Critical Cases
Consider the case where \(A\) and \(B\) are vertices of \(E\). Due to the symmetry of the regular \(n\)-gon, we can compute the angle at various vertices \(V\). For example:
- In an equilateral triangle (\(n=3\)), if \(A\) and \(B\) are two vertices, choosing \(V\) as the third vertex gives an angle of \(120^\circ > 60^\circ = \frac{\pi}{3}\).
- In a square (\(n=4\)), if \(A\) and \(B\) are opposite vertices, choosing an adjacent vertex for \(V\) gives an angle of \(90^\circ\), equal to the internal angle. If \(A\) and \(B\) are adjacent vertices, choosing an opposite vertex gives an angle greater than \(90^\circ\).

In general, when \(A\) and \(B\) are vertices, the minimal angle achieved by choosing an appropriate \(V\) is at least the internal angle \(\frac{n-2}{n} \pi\). This is because the vertices are symmetrically distributed, and selecting \(V\) such that it is not too aligned with the direction of \(B - A\) ensures a sufficiently large angle.

For general points \(A\) and \(B\) inside \(E\), the angle can be larger due to continuity. If \(A\) and \(B\) are close together or in positions where the angle might be small for some \(V\), choosing a vertex \(V\) far from \(A\) and \(B\) (in terms of direction) makes the vectors \(\overrightarrow{VA}\) and \(\overrightarrow{VB}\) nearly opposite, resulting in an angle close to \(180^\circ\), which is greater than \(\frac{n-2}{n} \pi\) for \(n \geq 3\).

### Step 3: Ensuring the Path Lies Inside \(E\)
Since \(E\) is convex, the

result.summary: The proof proposes to join any two interior points A and B of the regular n-gon E by two straight-line segments A–V and V–B to a suitably chosen vertex V, treating these segments as circular arcs of infinite radius. It claims that, by symmetry and continuity, one can choose V so that the angle at V between VA and VB is at least \((1-2/n)\pi\). Finally, it appeals to the convexity of E to assert that both segments lie inside E.

issues.location: Step 1: Existence of a Suitable Vertex V
issues.text: “We claim that for any A and B inside E, there exists a vertex V such that the angle at V is at least \(\frac{n-2}{n}\pi\).”
issues.description: The proof asserts the existence of a vertex V giving the required angle by symmetry and continuity but provides no argument or construction to guarantee that such a vertex exists for arbitrary A and B.

issues.location: Step 1: Cosine formula setup
issues.description: The proof introduces the dot-product formula for the angle but never carries out any calculation or bound to show that for some vertex V, the inequality \(\cos \phi \le -\cos(2\pi/n)\) actually holds.

issues.location: Throughout
issues.text: “We will use straight line segments as our circular arcs, interpreting them as circular arcs with infinite radius, which is a common mathematical convention.”
issues.description: The proof replaces genuine circular arcs with straight-line segments of infinite radius without justifying that these satisfy the problem requirement of circular arcs or addressing how to meet the angle condition using finite-radius arcs if required.

issues.location: Step 3 and beyond
issues.description: The proof is cut off mid-sentence in Step 3 and never completes the argument that the path lies inside E or ties together the existence and angle estimates to finish the proof.
